newsitem.title: BELGIUM: GAC to review former Yugoslavia developments.
newsitem.headline: GAC to review former Yugoslavia developments.

text.p: European Union foreign ministers will review the crisis in the rump Yugoslavia and the state of reconstruction aid in Bosnia at Monday's General Affairs Council, diplomats said.

They said the ministers would examine the report of former Spanish Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez on behalf of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) on the November 17 local elections.

Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic refused to accept the results of the polls which were won by the Zajedno (Together) coalition opposition, triggering huge street protests -- now in their 60th day -- in the biggest challenge yet to his 10-year rule.
The OSCE report vindicated the position of the opposition and said Milosevic should reverse a decision to annul the results.
The opposition has called for more international pressure to force the Serbian strongman to make concessions.
The ministers will also discuss an explicit refusal by Bosnian Serb President Biljana Plavsic to hand over indicted war criminals former Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and his army chief Ratko Mladic.
Plavsic said in a letter to U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan such a move would trigger "massive civil and military unrest".
The issue is unlikely to affect the flow of reconstruction aid to Bosnia, but could see some countries pledging less at a donors' conference slated for later this year.
A preparatory conference this month estimated the country would need $1.4 billion in 1997 to help it continue to recover from the brutal 3 1/2-year war.
